entry.title: OO Magic Bullet?
entry.content:
I do not think that there are any magic bullets, best practises can minimise risk but you have to fully understand the technique. You can not just switch from procedural code to wrapping everything in an object and claim statements like this from mathworks:

Because it was built using OO techniques, the application is now robust enough for others to use and maintain and can be integrated with related applications throughout an organization.

Sounds like Object-Oriented programming is a magic bullet to solve all you programming woes!

entry.title: Edit Octopress Posts
entry.content:
Creating new posts in Octopress is rake new_post["Edit Posts"] which outputs the created filename.

Posts are prefixed with date, which can make it difficult to find a particular post to edit. Tab completion can help if you known the year of the post but it may still list 100’s of posts where you have to spot the title, and narrow it done via month and day. To get around this I use this script to launch matching posts in my editor:

#!/bin/bash

editor="mvim"
post_path="source/_posts/"

for OUTPUT in $(ls $post_path | grep $1)
do
  file_list="$file_list $post_path$OUTPUT"
done

$editor $file_list

entry.title: $display Without a Line Return
entry.content:
In Verilog to output to stdout without a line return use $write();

Equivalent statements :

$write("\n");
$display("");

entry.title: Gnome: Disable Focus Tracking
entry.content:
Sometime ago I enabled focus tracking the mouse on Gnome. It took a while to find how to disable it again, so with out further a do the setting can be found in:

System -> Preferences -> Windows

§

entry.title: Rocket
entry.content:
On Saturday I placed Rocket seeds in my propagator and by Tuesday it had germinated and started to sprout.

So far so good:

entry.title: Propagator
entry.content:
I have always had trouble getting seeds to germinate, therefore I have purchased a propagator to help. Ideally I would have a thermostatically controlled unit, but they tend to be a bit more expensive, and non-looked like they wood fit nicely on a windowsill.

Garland Super7, should raise soil temperature by 8 degrees but fluctions of indoor temp will be passed on:

Hopefully I will have some better luck in the future.

entry.title: Monkey Patch Octopress
entry.content:
Based on post_filters by imathis.

First Move the original method out the way with alias_method then create a new method with the original name, calling the original now aliased method if required.

module Jekyll
  class URL
    alias_method :old_sanitize_url, :sanitize_url
    def sanitize_url(in_url)
      old_sanitize_url(in_url).downcase
    end
  end
end

This was used to build my Octopress plugin octopress_url_downcase.

entry.title: Raised Bed
entry.content:
Putting together my first raised bed, 8 foot by 2 foot, 1 plank high.

Cut parts ready for assembly:

The timber is pressure treated softwood from Drem Timber. Cost is around £14 for 16 foot (4.8m).

Parts I got:

4 * 8 foot (2 * 4.8m)
8 * 2 foot (1 * 4.8m)
8 corner stakes (£1 each)
--
£49

Using right angle clamps to assemble first corner.

Holding the spikes in place with quick clamps.

Constructing the second corner.

The final side and 2 corners, using 4 right angle clamps to hold it all in place.

entry.title: Beef Wellington
entry.content:
Based on :
Jamie Olivers Minced Beef Wellington from Jamie’s Ministry of Food.

Ingredients (for 4-6) :

  1         Large Potato
  1         Medium Onion
  1         Carrot
  1  Stick  Celery
  2  Cloves Garlic
  2         Large Mushrooms
  4  Sprigs Fresh Rosemarry
 50 g       Frozen Peas
  1         Large Egg
500 g       Puff Pastry (or 2 300g sheets)

Pre-heat oven to 180.

  1         Large Potato
  1         Medium Onion
  1         Carrot
  1  Stick  Celery

Add a olive oil to a frying pan start on a medium heat. Chop vegetables in to 1cm cubes, Potatoes, Onion, Carrot and Celery. Add to frying pan as you go.

  2  Cloves Garlic
  2         Large Mushrooms

Grate garlic into pan, rough chop mushrooms into 1cm chunks. 

  4  Sprigs Fresh Rosemarry

Remove Rosemary leaves and finely dice. 

 50 g       Frozen Peas

After 8 minutes, add frozen peas to pan and cook for 1 minute more. 

  1/2       Large Egg

Move mixture to a large mixing bowl to cool, Once cool mix in the beef with salt and half a beaten egg. 

500 g       Puff Pastry (or 2 300g sheets)
  1/2       Large Egg

Roll out the pastry into tea towel size, or unroll the sheets. Add mixture into the middle and roll up sealing the ends. Apply second half of beaten egg to the top of the wellington with a pastry brush.

Put in the oven for 180 Degrees for an hour.

entry.title: Matlab: Legend Colours
entry.content:
When plotting several lines in Matlab, I have become aware of how hard it was to see the colours in the legend. Based on this matlabcentral question I found an easy way to control the line thickness in the legend.

plot(randn(100,1));
hold on;
plot(randn(100,1),'k');


[legh,objh,outh,outm] = legend('First','Second','Location','Southeast');
set(objh,'linewidth',2); %%<-- set legend line thickness to 2

Or just the following after you define your legend:

% legend('First','Second','Location','Southeast');

[legh,objh,outh,outm] = legend();
set(objh,'linewidth',2);

entry.title: Matlab Benchmarking
entry.content:
In the following example we test the allocation speed of different types:

samples_to_avg = 10000;
for i=1:samples_to_avg
  tic; t = int8(zeros(32,2^16)); b(i) = toc;
end
avg_int8 = mean(b);

for i=1:samples_to_avg
  tic; t = zeros(32,2^16); b(i) = toc;
end
avg_double = mean(b);

%int 8 is
disp(['int8 pre-allocation is ', num2str(1 - avg_double/avg_int8), ' times faster than doubles'])

entry.title: Matlab Remove Values From Array
entry.content:
Remove all values of 3 from array

a = [1 2 3 4 3];
a(any(a==3,1)) = []
a =


     1     2     4

Remove 2 or less from array

a = [1 2 3 4 3];
a(any(a<=2,1)) = []
a =


     3     4     3

Remove values between 2 and 3

a = [1 2 3 4 3];
a(any((a>=2)&(a<=3),1)) = []
a =


     1     4

Based on examples from matlabnewbie.

entry.title: Brew Update Fail
entry.content:
Received the following errors when doing brew update on mountain lion:

error: The following untracked working tree files would be overwritten by merge:
        Library/Formula/platypus.rb
Please move or remove them before you can merge.
Aborting
Error: Failure while executing: git pull -q origin refs/heads/master:refs/remotes/origin/master

A solution found on Stackoverflow

cd /usr/local
git fetch origin
git reset --hard origin/master

entry.title: BirdBox
entry.content:
Dunbar Garden Centre Over Jan & Feb 2014 ran a 2 for £12 offer on Chapelwood bird boxes. Due to some extra vouchers we got these two for 95 pence.

Instructions that came with them:

Locate at height 2-5m off the ground, shelter from strong winds and direct sunlight. Do not locate adjacent to feeding sites.

Do not disturb once it is in use, clean out once a year between September and October, always wear rubber gloves.

entry.title: Garden Design Books
entry.content:
2013 I got my first garden and I had no idea where to begin. So I picked up a few books on garden design with good reviews, they were:

  1. Small Garden, John Brookes
  2. Big Plans Small Gardens, Andy Sturgeon
  3. The Garden Planner, Robin Williams
  4. All About Creating Japanese Gardens, Alvin Horton

The first 2 are great books to flick through a get ideas and inspiration. The Garden Planner focuses a lot on garden layout, all ideas are communicated well with floorplans and sketches of how it might look. All About Creating Japanese Gardens is as you might guess very specific in its styling, and includes good pictures and ideas.

As a first set of garden design books very happy with these, although drop the last one if your not interested in Japanese gardens.

Just in case I have messed up the links:

entry.title: Coffee Table
entry.content:
In 2007 I built our coffee table from 2.5” thick Elm purchased from Lanarkshire Hardwoods.

The wood was rough sanded. For the finish it took about 48 hours of sanding with a belt sander, and finished with Danish oil.
